Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Volar Locking Plate Fixation in Low-Grade Open vs. Closed Distal Radius Fractures

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients with Gustilo and Anderson Type I or II open DRFs. Participants were treated at a single orthopedic center.

Intervention.evidence: This study aimed to compare the outcomes of volar locking plate fixation in low-grade open distal radius fractures (DRFs) versus closed DRFs.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the outcomes of volar locking plate fixation in low-grade open distal radius fractures (DRFs) versus closed DRFs.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder, and Hand (DASH) score, measured at 3 months and 1 year postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This randomised controlled trial included 60 participants, with 20 patients in the open fracture group and 40 in the closed fracture group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 3 months, the closed fracture group showed better wrist flexion, extension, grip strength, and DASH scores. However, at 1 year, no significant differences were observed between the groups in functional outcomes.

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported.
